poem:
**October Lingering**

Swallows skitter through stables,  
autumn air tinged with grief,  
as oak roots clutch memory's soil.  
They balance flight and earth—  
young wings half-beat against  
the pull of a fallen branch.  
The season's pulse,  
steady yet uncertain,  
whispers the same as the oak:  
order endures, life is stitched,  
unrushed, through all things.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: There’s something cooking in the woods | Kate Blincoe The swallows lingered into mid‑October, the young hanging around in the stables, clumsily practising flight. I began to wonder if they would stay, if the system was somehow broken. Maybe I feel this way because the great oak of our family has fallen. My grandfather has died, just before turning 101, sharp of mind to the end. But order continues and the swallows too have now". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Country diary: There’s something cooking in the woods | Kate Blincoe The swallows lingered into mid‑October, the young hanging around in the stables, clumsily practising flight. I began to wonder if they would stay, if the system was somehow broken. Maybe I feel this way because the great oak of our family has fallen. My grandfather has died, just before turning 101, sharp of mind to the end. But order continues and the swallows too have now
